Expectation1: Maintain regular communication with family members
Situation1: A family member has a new job and has shared some initial excitement about it with their relatives.
Expectation2: Ensure compliance with safety and regulatory standards
Situation2: A routine audit is scheduled far ahead, leaving ample time to update documentation
Story: I sat at my kitchen table, my phone buzzing with a new message from my granddaughter. She’d just started her first job, and her excitement was contagious. She wanted to call and tell me all about her first week, and I knew how much it meant to her that I listened, that I was present for these milestones. At the same time, my laptop screen glowed with spreadsheets and safety checklists. The routine audit at work was months away, but I’d promised myself and my team that this time, every document would be flawless, every standard met ahead of schedule. My manager expected nothing less, and I prided myself on never letting things slide. I could feel the tug in my chest—my family needed my attention, my warmth, my presence. My profession demanded diligence, foresight, and hours of focused work. I stared at the phone, then at the screen, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in, each expecting me to be fully theirs.
